utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I was just bringing my son and he's just had cough for the last couple of days. I thought about a day and a half ago, it doesn't feel like a cold. He hasn't been too sick, but I was a little bit worried and I wanted to get him seen to see if there's anything we could do.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, for sure. It's a good thing that you brought him in. So the cough, is it consistent? Or does it come and go?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It seems to be a little bit worse at night. He'll have this cough during the day. Sometimes I'll notice when he's playing. He's had these coughing fits that last for up to a minute but usually recovers from. He hasn't been too active to be honest. He's been a little bit slowed down these last couple of days, but in regards to consistency, I'd say it's a little bit worse at night.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any other triggers like dust or the cold air? Anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I haven't really noticed anything. We've been mainly keeping inside due to covid, right? I think my wife left a window open the other night, and maybe the cough was a little bit better. I'm not sure. It's kind of hard to tell when we sleep.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, have you tried anything for it, like have you given him any over the counter cough medications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, we're a little scared to give him anything. He's so young. He's 2 1/2. We haven't been really giving him any medications to be honest.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good. And if you were to describe the quality of this cough, would you say it's barky? Is it harsh?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Barky might be a good word to describe it, like he's had colds before his coughs were quiet but this sounds harsh. It sounds like he's really trying to cough hard there. Very violent sometimes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK OK. And has he ever had a cough like this in the past?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, never.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then in terms of the timeline, is it getting worse? His cough?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I think it has been to be honest. He was a little ill like he had a runny nose a couple of days ago, maybe two days ago and then the cough started but it only really started getting noticeably different about the night of the first day, about two days ago so. Now it's been more present I suppose,than it was when he just first had it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and is it a dry cough or does he bring up sputum?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Sputum like phlegm,no he doesn't bring anything up really, so dry.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK so no blood as well right?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No blood.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK,  does he have any shortness of breath with his cough?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I feel like when he has the coughing fits, he's winded. He's weak after them. Sometimes he cries after them or before the middle can be a trigger for it, but just resting normally, he doesn't seem that out of breath, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK any wheeziness?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not really. He's able to breathe. I can't really hear him breathing that much. Sometimes at night after a bad cough he'll be really winded. And yeah, it does sound like a little different when he's breathing, but just right now he sounds normal.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and any reason for you to think he has chest pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: He hasn't any sort of chest pain. He says his throat hurts, but I don't think it's his chest.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Has he had any fevers?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any change in his hair, nails or skin like rashes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no rashes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: How about weight loss?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No weight loss, he's a fairly healthy kid.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And his vision and hearing are normal?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: You know, I haven't gotten him formally assessed yet, but seems to be able to read pretty well from a distance. He's not in school yet, but I haven't noticed anything, and he can hear fine. I think he responds when I call.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, has he had a stuffy or runny nose?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah yeah, that's kind of how it first started three days ago. Maybe had a runny nose. OK, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Does he still have a runny nose?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Umm, a little bit less now. No, not as much now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And his taste, any reason to believe there are any changes there?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Well, we've been kind of spoiling him a bit, just giving him ice cream. His throat hurts a little bit and he seems to still like it, so it's hard to tell.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so he has a little bit of a sore throat as well?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK OK, and then any dizziness or fainting spells that you've noticed?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No fainting or dizzy spells, but he's really gassed after he has like a coughing fit and he doesn't want to stand up, he'll just be sitting down or he wants to be held.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, is he more irritable than usual?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah after he has a bad coughing fit, he wants to be soothed and he'll be crying, but it's just more of because he's worn out, I believe he's tired.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, OK, and then any confusion or memory loss?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then in terms of his bowel movements, have things been normal from that standpoint?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh yeah, process of potty training him, but no, no real changes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so no diarrhea, no constipation, no blood in the stool?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and he's passing gas?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: OK yeah I'd say so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any nausea or vomiting?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No. We haven't been really feeding him solid meals, it's because he's been sick, we've been trying to give him soup and liquids for the most part because his throat hurts, but he's able to keep them down. So no, no nausea, no vomiting.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then how about changes in his appetite?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, he's not eating as much but still, we're trying to force food into him to keep his energy up. Most of time he always will be asking for snacks in the afternoon, but now not so much.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Alright and any anything else that I missed that he's been experiencing over the past few days?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, just the cough.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then he otherwise healthy? Does he have any longstanding medical conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No longstanding medical conditions. Yeah, nothing really. We had a little bit of stay in the NICU, just because he was a little bit underweight, but no, nothing really.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And then his mother's pregnancy with him? Any complications at that point?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah he's a little pre term. 34 weeks I think.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, was he also underweight too?  You mentioned just a little bit.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and any complications during the actual delivery?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, not that I remember like she started going to labor early, like earlier than we expected. We thought it was just a regular contraction and that it will just resolve but she wound up proceeding when we showed up at the hospital

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and then in terms of growth, weight and head circumference, has he been hitting all those milestones for the past 2 1/2 years?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, we we bring him to the family doctor every couple of month for his regular checkups and nothing has been brought up to be concerning for his vaccines. He has been doing well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and then how about other milestones like speech, movement, fine movement, all of that, like have those been normal? Is he on par with his peers?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, this is our first kid, but compared to his cousins he seems to be doing well. He's speaking, he's got little sentences, now he has good eye contact. He's a good kid.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good good. Any hospitalizations or surgeries aside from when he was born?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK good and is he on any medications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, OK we give him like a flintstone gummy.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, is he up to date with all his immunizations?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any allergies?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Not that we know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any family history of lung conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So my grandfather, so his greatgrandfather I suppose passed away from lung cancer. He was a heavy smoker though. On my mom's side there's some breast cancer. No,  nothing really that comes to mind for lungs.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And any heart conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not that we know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And how about other cancers?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not that I know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how about asthma, eczema or allergies in the family?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: You know, I think my sister is allergic to peas, but she was never sick from them like go to the hospital.  I don't think there are any allergies in the family.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good, has he been in contact with anyone who's been sick recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: You know, like 5 days ago we had a playdate with his cousin. And we kind of thought that that's where he got the cold from. Like the runny nose, but it just turned weird, you know.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and how's this cousin doing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Last time I talked to Charlotte, Hank seems to be doing well so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and has he traveled to anywhere recently? Have you any of you traveled anywhere recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, with covid and everything, we have just been keeping to ourselves.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And with who and where does he live?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: He lives with me and his mother in a house

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Any old carpets or mold or concerns for asbestos? Anything like that at home?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I don't know when this house is built. I don't think there's any asbestos in it and it's all hardwood. So no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good. Anyone at home smoke?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good. So those were all the questions that I had. Do you have any questions for me?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no that's it, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, well, from the sounds of it, he most likely has some sort of viral infection. We will do a COVID swap to rule that out because some symptoms do seem to overlap with COVID and we want to make sure to rule that out. So we'll take a swab. Those PCR results should come back in about 24 to 48 hours. In the meantime, he should isolate for 14 days at home and if it's not COVID, it could be another viral infection like parainfluenza, also known as croup. So for that, for any of these viral infections, actually the best treatment is to stay at home and make sure that he's very well hydrated and eating well. If his symptoms persist for three to five days or more, or if his symptoms worsen, especially if he has like a seizure or urological issues, he should go to the ER and if his symptoms do become worse, we can also prescribe him some steroids or epinephrine just to open up his airways. And if it's really, really bad he might be hospitalised as well. So just keep an eye on on that for now. And if you have any questions or concerns, just give us a call. How does that sound?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: A little scary. Sounds good. OK, I'll just keep an eye on him for the next five days.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Give us a call if his symptoms are becoming worse or if they're not resolving and we will try to do an assessment on him. Of course we will do a physical exam today and will let you know how severe his symptoms are. Most children will get over their infection on their own and he likely won't need any additional treatments.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: OK, sounds good.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright take care.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
